The success of the original songs on the first two covers-heavy Beatles LP's convinced John Lennon and Paul McCartney to pen an entire set of new songs for the third outing. The band is a few years away from transcending their initial influences or acquiring new ones, but an album of all-original material was still a bold step in their growth as artists.

Most of the strengths of the Fab Four's nascent efforts are explored and strengthened here. "If I Fell" has a gorgeous arrangement of the harmony singing that The Beatles gleaned off 1960's R&B girl groups. "Can't Buy Me Love" emulates the rollicking tone of Buddy Holly and Elvis Presley so wonderfully that one could be forgiven for thinking that it's a cover of an old rockabilly single. "I'm Happy Just To Dance With You" charts George Harrison's growing confidence as a songwriter. "And I Love Her" boasts one of the prettiest melodies that Paul McCartney ever penned. Of course, there's also the goofy lyrics and thrusting energy of the title cut.

A Hard Day's Night possesses an embarrassment of riches that builds off the foundation of Little Richard, Chuck Berry, the catalog of Motown, and The Beatles' prior accomplishments. No overview of modern pop music would be complete without a hard look at this band and no overview of The Beatles would be complete without a hard look at A Hard Day's Night.

With this epochal release, the Beatles establish themselves as a rock band like no other before, or no other since.

Bear in mind here, the group was undertaking a punishing schedule throughout the first half of 1964. A world tour, a whirlwind first stop in the United States, filming a movie, and trips in and out of the studio in-between it all; if there was ever a time to release an album of cover tunes, outtakes, or otherwise inferior material to simply promote the movie, the Beatles had the perfect excuse to do so, and nobody would've blame them. Instead, they turn in rock's very first fully self-contained album. John Lennon and Paul McCartney author all the tracks here, the first and last time they were to do so. And these weren't just knocked off tracks either; every song here is a classic, showing a rapidly developing penchant for songwriting that was leaving every other seasoned professional songwriter, even the Brill Building, in the dust. And the instruments and vocals were all Beatles, except for the occasional piano from producer George Martin. Nowhere will you find the true spirit of the peak of Beatlemania than here, this very album. 

The title track grabs your attention from the very first chord, George's Fadd9 played on the Rickenbacker 360/12 12-string guitar, and from there the entire album doesn't let up. The songs thematically aren't derivative of anything they've done before, but they're written and executed as the sum of all their influences: early rock `n roll, soul, R&B, girl groups, Motown, and pop standards, blended together brilliantly, often within the same song.

It should also be noted that this is the first Beatles album recorded on a then-state-of-the-art four track machine, allowing for better mixing, re-doing different instrumental or vocal performances, and for the first time, overdubbing. From here, Beatle product from the studio would grow increasingly sophisticated as they develop. But this album would become their first truly influential release, as people like Brian Wilson, Bob Dylan and Roger McGuinn were taking extensive notes on their music by this time.

One of the greatest rock albums of the 60's (and all time) and one of the first Beatles records I truly fell in love with. A Hard Day's Night is the sound of the first British invasion in all it's wild and exciting fun. This is kind of record that you would play on Friday or Saturday night out and dance your ass of too it (much like Little Richard's Here's Little Richard, who clearly influenced John Lennon's powerful vocal style in those famed early Beatles recordings). The record is admittedly top loaded (all the best songs, which just happen to form the soundtrack to the movie, make up the entire first side) but it spaces warm, romantic ballads in between faster dance numbers. It starts off nicely with the epic Friday night anthem that is the title track which gets the party going and the feeling continues with I Should Have Known Better before cooling down for a moment with the wistful romantic ballad If I Fell and the sensual, Spanish flavored And I Love Her which are only interrupted by the brief dance interlude I'm Happy Just to Dance With You before picking up pace with immensely fun and catchy Tell Me Why (arguably The Beatles most underrated album track) before hitting a major peak with the show shopping dance song Can't Buy Me Love, one of my favorite Beatles songs. Side two keeps up much of the same energy on tracks like Anytime at All, I'll Cry Instead and You Can't do That, it also contributes completely different feeling that's a bit more moody in nature. If side one captured the peak of Beatlemania, then side two not only does this but subtly shows the direction(s) The Beatles were heading in with their next records. Things We Said Today forms the heart of this second side and it's arguably the most haunting song The Beatles ever recorded as it brings to mind the haunting style of Roy Orbison while When I Get Home is rather angry in nature and I'll Be Back is rather poignant in nature. I personally recommend this for Beatles neophytes as being their first Beatles record to check out.

Certainly the most experimental Beatles album to this point in their history, Revolver is also arguably one of the riskiest of their entire catalog. The hints of psychedelia and the more mature lyrical subject matter found on Rubber Soul became much more overt on Revolver. Considering that just two years earlier, these guys were recording simpler stuff like "I Want to Hold Your Hand" only two years older, it is astounding how far their music had matured. Even more impressive, as that all of this exploration happened without Lennon and McCartney losing their sense for great pop music. "Eleanor Rigby," "I'm Only Sleeping," "Yellow Submarine," and "And Your Bird Can Sing" are all terrific to listen to. It's easy to see how this album inspired musicians everywhere to take new leaps with their own music, or just to start bands of their own. It's a monumental album not only in the Beatles catalog, but in the history of popular Western music.

LSD, experimentation, sitar - and all this to a background of the best Beatles' charm...

Best song: TOMORROW NEVER KNOWS

If Rubber Soul only treaded water in the matters of turning pop-rock into art-rock, then Revolver is the first major art-rock piece by the Fab Four - not conceptual yet, because it lacks an obvious linking theme (if you don't count the amount of acid-induced product, of course), but the first utterly 'serious' album in rock. John has begun his experiments with LSD, and they resulted in the first openly psychedelic songs. The groovy thanatological 'She Said She Said' has never fascinated me, to tell the truth, because I've always felt it was somewhat overproduced; yet it was a milestone in the history of rock lyrics, as the first masked description of an acid trip and its, er, 'side effects'. But the apocalyptic 'Tomorrow Never Knows' was an even bigger milestone - basically, it's a rather simple, drooling melody that one'd expect from bands like the Velvet Underground (for a really, I mean really boring version check out Anthology II), but it's stuffed up with quite a lot of funny little noises obviously reflecting the state of mind in a... oh. You know where. First of all, John lets his voice pass through some gadget so that it manages to sound otherworldly; next, they record a 'wall-of-sound' background track with probably all the instruments they managed to get in the studio, and finally they spice it all up with backwards tapes and such-like stuff to make the most terrific, most representative musical image of a journey through your subconscious ever created by mankind. No kidding.


Even the album cover now is fully schizophrenic: four rough sketches of the Beatles' faces (almost unrecognizable, as a matter of fact) interspersed with lots of smaller photos of the Beatles and other persons; indeed, the cover to Revolver is the first step towards the cover to Sergeant Pepper. And, as usual, no filler. Why is it 'Revolver', I wonder? Did they mean it would produce the same effect?

"Revolver" is The Beatles at their peak of creativity. Surprising shifts in mood prevail on this album--ranging from the bright positivity of "Good Day Sunshine" to the paranoia of "She Said She Said." The balance of pure harmony {"Here There and Everywhere"} with jangling electric guitar {"And Your Bird Can Sing"], orchestral character portraits {"Eleanor Rigby"} and brassy soul {Got to Get You Into My Life"} is seamless. "Revolver" is also one of the first psychedelic albums--with backwards guitar, sitar, sound affects, and complex lyrics throughout--culminating in the mystical finale of "Tomorrow Never Knows." Filled with revolutionary studio advances and perfect song craft, the end result is a towering artistic achievement.

If Rubber Soul was the pot album, Revolver was the acid album. In the months following Rubber Soul, the Beatles expand even further, making music so diverse, so concrete, so unique, so unlike anything anybody else was doing. It's on Revolver they sound so locked in to what they were producing, an immersive effort. Each member of the band giving 110% to the project and adding to as well as creating new musical identities. John's experiences with substances as well as his literary discoveries lead him into unexplored territory, Paul's amazing character studies lead him to see life from all sides, George grows his Indian music fascination deeper as well as looks below the surface at the problems of life, and Ringo provides arguably the best drumming of his Beatles career, and sings with style on Yellow Submarine. So many styles, so many trips, so many experiences, and it's all here. Revolver. Key tracks are Taxman, Eleanor Rigby, Here There And Everywhere, Yellow Submarine, She Said She Said, For No One, Got To Get You Into My Life, and Tomorrow Never Knows.

This was the first album i bought (on casette 1993) and i become a psychadelia fanatic after hear it...i love The Beatles hits since i was a child but this was mind-blowing...this album makes me a rock albums collector...masterpiece!

The Beatles have grown up. Their first venture into psychedelia is one of their most enduring albums for the production value alone; George Martin is as important here as anyone. The Beatles are clearly influenced by the two Dylan albums released since Rubber Soul as well as their own psychedelic experiences and this is the album where George Harrison really emerges as a strong songwriter in his own right. This sounds much more relevant today that Sgt. Pepper's.

"Sgt. Pepper's" overarching concept of a variety show performance is, paradoxically, what makes it a totally cohesive and coherent album. "Revolver" has no such linking narrative, not even a sketchy and tentative one like "Pepper's", yet the LP is frequently held up not only as the greatest Beatles record, but one of the greatest records ever made. As a set of individual tracks which push the boundaries of pop's sonics and subject matter, "Revolver" is a significant release. But as a body of songs its legacy is less heartening because the Beatles now prize mature experimentalism over instinctive ensemble playing. You can hear it in the way elements of the songs sound cobbled together (much like the album's extraordinary cover art), and how the songs in different styles rub uncomfortably up against one another. The overall impression is that McCartney, Lennon, and the increasingly disingenuous Harrison (Taxman is a rich rock star's moan about, well, having to pay tax) are working more at odds to each other than is good for them, although, unlike on "The White Album", the Beatles are still capable of demonstrating a bit of discipline. With musicians of the calibre of the Beatles, it was too much to expect they'd simply knock out great songs in the studio, working together as a proper band, forever. But whenever I listen to "Revolver", I pine for the sound of the tight ensemble playing heard on past releases; and it is the sort of critical snobbery that arises from notions of 'maturity' in rock (a misnomer), and eclecticism and experimentalism as ends in themselves, which prevent truly great rock records like "A Hard Day's Night" being routinely elevated up to the kind of exalted status that "Revolver" so undeservedly enjoys.

The Beatles of 1966. Danger and death threats, dark shades and chain smoke. Before Sgt. Pepper and the Summer of Love, the Fabs crafted this lean and mean modern pop/rock masterwork. Supremely confident and at the peak of their powers, they left their contemporaries Dylan, the Stones and Brian Wilson miles in the rear view and set the bar for generations to come. Best songs. Best vocals. Best guitars. Best production. Ever.
A mesmerizing piece of art that strengthens the foundations of a musical movement at the time. What was accomplished here is truly admirable.

I hate that people think Sgt. Peppers is the pinnacle of The Beatles work. It didn't get better than Sgt. Pepper they say. I disagree. Revolver is possibly the greatest album the group ever did. Tomorrow Never Knows, Yellow Submarine, Taxman, Got To Get You Into My Life (my favorite track on the album) Love You To, Elanor Rigby, do I need to say more? This was possibly the most important album they ever did. I don't need to go into detail since everybody knows how amazing Revolver is.It basically foreshadowed the Summer of Love with Pet Sounds. The group knew what they were doing and I absolutely love this album. Fantastic production that still sounds great to this day, a timeless classic. Trust me, Sgt Peppers is Awesome as well, but Revolver is five times better than Sgt Pepper.

I almost feel nervous giving the Album 'just' four and a half out of five, but I'll try and justify it as best I can. Perhaps the Songs have become so timeless, some of them from my own early childhood recollection (Yellow Submarine) I was aware of certain tracks before giving the Album a listen as a whole, so I subsequently feel the occasional temptation to skip certain ones. I also sense that the keenness from the group to experiment and push boundaries musically (which should only ever be commended in any case) perhaps detracts focus as to what sounds exactly they're trying to achieve here. I'm not saying the album sounds confused, but there are certainly a lot of cooks stirring the pot here (for want of a better phrase) which to me signifies contention and perhaps even slightly reluctant toleration of input from certain members. I understand that all of these are potentially (probably are in fact) exactly what makes this Album great, and maybe I should be interpreting the Album as a pioneering Audio experience rather than a Band simply putting out another Record. It's literally my favorite Beatles Album, feels a bit weird saying so after all that.

After all these years, this still seems like, song for song, the best album of the rock era. It was also the real watershed in The Beatles career, even if Sgt. Pepper had a deeper cultural resonance. The true great leap forward that ushered in an era, for better or for worse, of "important" rock albums.

I don't think I've ever seen a bad review of this album and I'm not about to buck the trend. The only song I could do without is Dr. Robert - but that's just a matter of personal preference. If you were looking for a perfect album, this is it.

I think this album also tends to mark the beginning of the shift from John as the dominant personality in the band to Paul. While John is by no means a secondary talent when compared with other contemporary artists, Paul emerges on Revolver as the stronger talent and I don't know that he ever relinquishes his hold within the band from this point forward.

I don't think I've ever seen a bad review of this album and I'm not about to buck the trend. The only song I could do without is Dr. Robert - but that's just a matter of personal preference. If you were looking for a perfect album, this is it.
