Ha! They don't remember recording this one! Wheeeeeee! Our parent's generational poster-boys begin their long and winding trip through the newspaper taxis and the first taste is a dark one. The cover for this record is just about a perfect representation of what's inside...kinda confused and morphing, but still recognizable as coming from the throbbing melodic centres that the previous stuff was excreted from. Take, what I consider to be the quintessential Revolver song, 'Elenor Rigby', which contains nary a single normal rock instrument. It's all done by strings! That's right! The things your 5th grade orchestra class couldn't stop sounding like cats having their dermis torn from their subcutaneous muscle! And its all about sad and lonely old people and the weird rituals they go through to keep from feeling useless. Happy!

Now they do something interesting here (like they ever don't) ona few tracks, and take their Rubber Soul R&B/folk mix and fuse it! What a great idea! Like 'I'm Only Sleeping'...that strumming is pure folk rock (just slowed waaaaaaaay down) but that singing is pure Motown, man. 'Here, There, and Everywhere' does a lot of the same thing, but this time the singing is from the mid 50's doo-woppers rather than the mid-60's dancehall champions. Oh, 'Good Day Sunshine' is pure Lovin' Spoonful-esque cute optimism (thanks for the ray of light, Paul) folk rock, and 'For No One' is pure bummer folk-rocking, and 'Got To Get You Into My Life' is just 100% honkin' soul, so not everything undergoes 'the change', and really, all those songs I just listed are equally triumphant in my book.

For the songs that go way out to the Oort cloud, I shall nominate, but of course, 'Tomorrow Never Knows' as the top Beatles psychedelic song ever. And one of their top songs ever, period. And why? Take those backwards bird caws, that perfectly insistent, heaving funk beat, John's 'turn on your mind, relax, and float downstream' and 'love is all and love is everyone' and I see, IMHO, that all of their further psychedelia was simply attempting to recapture this peak. They never did it this cool again, not even on 'Strawberry Fields' OR 'A Day In The Life' OR 'LSD'. There's also 'She Said She Said', about Peter Fonda's acid trip, and its okay...but it's sorta just another song, you know? And 'Dr. Robert' is even more MOR than that. Bo-ring. For the Beatles. A highlight for 90% of the bands out there.

George's opening 'Taxman' is interesting, though, for besides it's itchy rocking nag, it also holds a sort of conservative social message (a Beatles first, both the social message and the conservative part, which was probably also a Beatles last). Weird huh? Maybe George should have run for MP on the Tory ticket. George's other weird tune on here is 'Love You Too', showing how far he's coming with those raga lessons on that sitar. But you know what? It rocks too, and not in spite of its Indian fetishism but because of it.

Revolver is a true work of genius, tackling both adventurous and more mundane material and excelling at both. The experimentation never hinders the melodies, rather enabling the melodies to go in new directions never thought possible, transcending the medium as a whole. Bereft of filler and infused with a healthy dose of the Beatles' special magic, Revolver is a timeless classic, a masterpiece that still sounds just as fresh today as it did decades ago, with Tomorrow Never Knows somehow sounding just as cutting edge as it had at its initial creation. For both innovation and melody Revolver can't be topped, making the album not only one of the Beatles' finest but likewise one of the greatest albums of all time.

Forgive me if I gush a bit too much in this review, but I'll just have to make this clear up front. This here album is, BY FAR, my favorite album of all time. PERIOD. When I took this sucker home after getting it from Best Buy and listened to it breathlessly four times straight before having to go, I knew from that point onwards that I would never again feel guilty about loving the Beatles. Anyways, I've tried to avoid going into too much detail about individual songs in the rest of my reviews for the group, but because I am scared that somebody might not actually be totally familiar with this simply amazing work of art, please allow me this indulgence.

In any case, if you don't agree with me giving the highest Beatles rating to Revolver, that's fine. Anything from Rubber Soul through Abbey Road is fine by me. But, I will tell you what I feel pushes Revolver over the top. While the individual songwriting abilities of the Fab 4 had yet to peak, this is the last time that I hear them truly functioning as a band. Sure, the bickering wouldn't start until The Beatles, but this was the last album where the band didn't have a true 'leader', if you get my drift. And with all of these monumental songwriting forces combined into one (along with producer George Martin, who deserves a TON of credit for this album), it should be little wonder that they produced such an incredible masterpiece. And with that I close. Amen.

Rubber Soul may be their first attempt on a more sober and complete album, but Revolver was clearly the departing point. Here, they find no limits to their creativity, expanding their ideas, breaking boundaries and find different perspectives and approaches to music. They started to use the studio as instrument, particularly using samples and loops, which was completely new at that time. But it was not only their approach which was different. Their sound was changing. They were rocking harder then before. And the mix of these two aspects result in their most psychedelic album. There are some highlights in this album (which rank quite high in their career as well), and fantastic individual performances. Ringo inventive percussion on "She Said She Said" is absolutely amazing and Harrison's guitar is incredibly tight, detailed and impeccable. John Lennon shines on "Tomorrow Never Knows" with his psychedelic deliver and Paul McCartney shows why he is probably the best melodicist ever on "Got To Get Into My Life". It may not be their best album, but it is their most adventurous, psychedelic and guitar driven one.

Another complete breakthrough by the Beatles - earlier advances were steady and significant but predictable, paralleled by those of other artists like Dylan and the Beach Boys. Revolver isn't as carefully crafted and relentlessly tuneful as Pet Sounds, but it's even more important, pushing the sonic boundaries of rock farther than any other LP in history. The Beatles combine startling studio wizardry ("Tomorrow Never Knows") with inventive lyrical themes (John's "I'm Only Sleeping" and "She Said She Said") and unusual instrumentation (George's "Love You Too" - which kicked open rock's door to Eastern music). Paul is in top form ("Eleanor Rigby"; the brassy "Got To Get You Into My Life"), George contributes the fantastically funky and ominous "Taxman," and, of course, there's everyone's all-time favorite sing-along novelty tune - "Yellow Submarine." The single that immediately preceded Revolver ("Paperback Writer"/"Rain") ranks with anything the Beatles ever did.

While Pepper would come to be regarded as a more culturally significant album, it wouldn't have been possibly without Rubber Soul and particularly Revolver. The only slight pity, at least for the band's personal artistic integrity, is that this turned out to be the final Beatles release that Dave Dexter would put his grubby meddling paws on. The Fab Four made sure that all changed from here on.

My favorite album by the Beatles. I really can't say there isn't a song that I don't like. Norwegian Wood is probably my favorite on the album. I just like the overall feel of the album. To me, every song is a classic. You can't go wrong with this album.

Rubber Soul was a turning point in the development of the Beatles, and sixties music generally. Faced with stiff competition from the likes of Dylan, the Beatles knew they had to abandon their earlier pure girly pop, and start to make music with more depth and substance to it. Rubber Soul contained the first excursions in that new direction, but still maintained the catchy and memorable nature of their earlier work.

What's remarkable about this album is that it sounds like it was written as an album, not just a collection of hits with fillers added to make up space. There's not one duffer on this album, every song is good and contributes something. Right from the beginning you can hear a change in their song format - songs were about something other than just love all the time (some of them contained humour, very unusual in pop at that time), and experimentation in musical style abounds. "Drive My Car" is a song not about love, but about ambition and materialism; it has the lads singing sound effects (beep beep) and a funny story with a punchline even ("I've got a driver, and that's a start."). "Norwegian Wood" is about revenge (Lennon later said that when he lit the fire, it was the house that was set aflame "isn't it good, Norwegian wood"), while "Run For Your Life" is about murderous revenge (Lennon was later sorry about this song, as it really is very misogynistic, but I suppose he made up for it later with "Woman"). Many of the themes were quite thoughtful - "Think For Yourself" is self explanatory, while "The Word" forsees the psychadelia and the summer of love yet to come.

Musically, the Beatles began to try out different things - sitar on "Nowegian Wood", powerful fuzz bass on "Think For Yourself", a harpsichord solo on "In My Life" (and very pleasant it is too)! "Michelle" is a fabulous ballad from McCartney with French overtones, while Lennon went for a more German sounding "Girl", clearly feeling the competition from McCartney's song. But the Beatles' earlier sound isn't missing either - the chiming guitars, the tambourine, the harmonics, can all be heard on songs like "You Won't See Me", and Harrison's "If I needed Someone".

Overall, this is a great album, full of catchy but interesting songs, the Beatles at the very peak of their songwriting and musical powers. This album acts as an interface between the early and later periods, and combines the best of both. If you haven't got Rubber Soul, your collection isn't complete!
I just want to say that this is my first Beatles album I got today and the album is really great!

US or UK version? I think no other lp in the Beatles canon illustrates this debate more clearly than here. Both versions are great, but also different in feel. The UK's version has 4 unique songs "Drive My Car", "Nowhere Man", "What Goes on" & "If I Needed Someone". Left on the UK version, you have basically the next great Beatles rock lp. Those songs were cut & saved for the later US lp "Yesterday & Today" and in their place the Sides openers became "I've Just Seen a Face" & "It's Only Love" for the US lp. With the rockier songs cut, the US lp had a coherently folk-rock acoustic feel, setting a distinct mood.

Many prefer the US version. I think re-inserting George's "If I Needed Someone" to the US lineup would make the perfect Rubber Soul. Whatever configuration, these are peak first period Beatle songs & it's nice to shuffle them up a bit for repeated listening.

The Beatles returned from the US, partly psychedelicised, having been heavily influenced by Bob Dylan and the emerging folk rock scene. "Nowhere Man" sounds like it could be a Byrds Song and you can hear the influence of Dylan all over the album. Indian music had been influencing Jazz music in the US for some time, American rock stars were influenced by Jazz and Harrison picked up the Sitar in the US, making "Norwegian Wood" one of, if not the first pop tune to use the instrument. This album is rated highly on best ever lists, but amongst classics like "Drive My Car", "Norwegian Wood", "Nowhere Man", "Michelle", "Girl" and "In My Life" there are plenty of ephemeral, unmemorable tunes, rushed out to get the album released in time for the Xmas market, that either weren't any good in the first place ("What Goes On") or that haven't aged well. That said, it's an important bridge between "Help" and "Revolver".

Rubber Soul is a giant leap forward for not only The Beatles, but the entire rock world. Expanding upon their sound, their words, and their use of the studio, this is the first album that sounded serious and exploratory in so many areas. An amazing degree of sophistication in not only the music but the lyrics. John and Paul are clearly exploring different avenues as musicians/writers, and those directions would expand on their unique gifts. George is becoming a much more creative force within the band and his musical expansion gives Rubber Soul such a diverse flavor. Ringo does sing What Goes On, but his timekeeping skills only help to enhance the overall sound of he and his bandmates. Key tracks are Drive My Car, Norwegian Wood (This Bird Has Flown), Nowhere Man, Michelle, I'm Looking Through You, In My Life, and If I Needed Someone.

The Beatles had already made five fantastic albums, and it couldn't last - or could it? Yes it could! They even even made their best album with their sixth album RUBBER SOUL. The first Beatles album which was one of the BIG 5 albums. "In My Life" is my favorite Beatles song. "Norwegian Wood", "You Drive My Car", "Michelle" etc. In fact, I could list all the 14 songs from this album - they all are great songs. This is a perfect album. They had made more sophisticated pop with the album HELP! and it was time to make their peak album, a landmark.

"Rubber Soul" marked a new period of development for The Beatles, illustrated by the sitar leads on "Norwegian Wood," the harpsichord effect on "In My Life," and Lennon's character portrait of "Nowhere Man." It exhibits not only a love for R&B, but also for the burgeoning folk-rock scene and exploding counter-culture. By 1965, the band was spending longer hours at the studio as both a refuge from the increasingly excitable outside world and as a place where their imaginations could flourish. As a result, "Rubber Soul" is a culmination of great depth, focus, and sophistication to create a startlingly original album.

The Beatles 6th studio album is without a doubt the most mature record of theirs. It shows the group moving on from the days where their albums were still great but filled with generic love songs and covers to more thoughful songs like "Nowehere Man" and "Think For Yourself" or songs that seem like love songs but have a dark humorous twist to them like "Drive My Car" and "Norweigan Wood" for example. Rubber Soul also marks the start of Paul McCartney's style of extremely meoldic bass playing that can't be ignored while listening (there are some earlier examples but most are singles like "She's A Woman") it adds a fun and enjoyable element to the listening experience, In addition to George Harrison's 12-string guitar folk rock playing style instead of his previous Carl Perkins style of playing that peaked in the Beatles earlier tracks, this album has very much a folk rock vibe to it which is quite a change from what we've been used to in terms of the Beatles. You can really feel the influence from The Byrds 1965 record "Mr. Tambourine Man. Fantastic album, one of my favourites of all time, never not worth a listen.

Here we get the beginning of the Beatles musical renaissance. This is their only full on entry into folk, and it is utter perfection and a unique item in their catalog, despite not actually straying THAT far from their earlier sound. Before this point the Beatles were basically all about writing whatever song would sell, by now they conquered that market and got bored so they decided to perfect the art of making music and expand horizons. Here they dip their feet in the water before going head first on their next LP.

It's still clear at this point that John in the leader of the band, in position and songwriting ability. John delivers what are the two best songs in my opinion, "In My Life" which has a fantastic piano solo played by George Martin, and the absolute classic "Nowhere Man" the Beatles second song not to address love and it is strikingly personal. John was confused as to his direction in life and after a long writers block awoke at night with the song formed in his head. The harmonies in the song are also fantastic. Many people like to take issue with "Run For Your Life" (including John) due to its misogynistic lyrics, but it works for me for two reasons. Number one, it's aggressive lyrics make it stand out from their other 'I Love You' songs (and the lyrics in these songs lets face it are mostly secondary concerns anyways) and two, John was an angry jealous person, and that shows in these lyrics, making this one of the more personal Beatle-mania songs. Then there's "Norweigan Wood" with its sitar usage making it an anomaly, and it's no secret Lennon was on another level.

That's not to make it seem like John is the only pulling force however, as there are truly no bad songs as everyone in the Fab Four gets at least one highlight. Paul has "Michelle", where McCartney is right in his wheelhouse, recording sweet and soft love songs. "I'm Looking Through You" also has some fine guitar work. George contributes two tracks, one with some interesting fuzz bass ("Think For Yourself") and another with a strong guitar riff ("If I Needed Someone") much like his tracks on Help! they blend in with the Lennon-McCartney tracks as George had yet to carve himself a unique identity. Ringo gets "What Goes On" which lets Ringo do what he does best, excel as the sympathetic loser while the rest of the Beatles sing glorious harmonies. Even though "Wait" was a leftover from the Help! sessions, nothing sounds out of place and every song is worthwhile.

Despite all this, from my searches online Rubber Soul seems to be an underdog as a candidate for the Beatles best album, and my guess is that it's too artsy for the elderly crowd who doesn't care for their experimental days, but not revolutionary enough for those who admire the Beatles ability to change the world of music. But straddling these lines is what makes the album so charming. For most bands, this would be a career highlight, for the Fab Four, it was just another stepping stone to greater feats.

Almost entirely unlike anything The Beatles had done previously, Rubber Soul is a superior album that finally embraces intelligent songwriting, unique tonal blends, and subtle psychedelic tendencies over the lovey-dovey material of before.

After three years, five albums, two movies, and a fist full of ground breaking singles, the Beatles had changed pop music and rock and roll and how it was made. Astonishingly, they would spend the next two years wiping this progress clean and changing it all AGAIN. And this is the starting point for that phase in their career. 

The group would start exploring lyrical themes that went beyond boy/girl relationships here. John Lennon's songs especially would reach a new level of introspection thanks to tracks like "Nowhere Man" and the touching future elegy "In My Life". George Harrison's songwriting was improving; "Think For Yourself" was lyrically important in the context of his solo career as it depicts a struggle from a lack of spirituality before it became a part of his life, and "If I Needed Someone" has a strong Roger McGuinn influence. 

The most notable thing about this album as a whole is the expansion of the group's sonic palette. They had flirted with unusual instrumentation as far back as "Don't Bother Me" on their second album, but here all sorts of new things are tried. Of course, it's the first instance of sitar in a pop song in "Norwegian Wood (This Bird has Flown)" after the scene in the movie Help! where a sitar group performs the song "A Hard Day's Night.. French-inspired guitar lines decorate Paul McCartney's "Michelle". George Martin's piano overdub sped up to sound like a harpsicord in "In My Life". The piano sound was heavily compressed on "The Word". A fuzz box was attached to Paul's bass on "Think for Yourself". Yet even these experiments were lightweight compared to what was to come. 

Influentially, this album was starting to show rock groups that the album could be used to make a strong statement, and Brian Wilson took notice and delivered his own "Pet Sounds" as a direct answer. But this was only the start of what could be done in a recording studio given some magnetic tape and a little imagination.

The album that blew Brian Wilson's mind, Rubber Soul was the album that saw The Beatles breaking away from the good time Beatlemania sounds of their previous records. Granted they had already begun that process on their previous two records, and they still manage to provide a nice good time for a good part of the record, Rubber Soul has them being a lot more reflective, personal, and exploratory such as through the usage of sitar on the lovely, reflective ballad Norwegian Wood (This Bird Has Flown), the gritty soul vibes of Drive My Car, the funky rhythms and proto-flower power lyrics of The Word, the mature, baroque inspired life reflection of In My Life (of which, a cover version by Chantal Kreviazuk would later be used as the theme song to the late 90's and early 2000's era TV drama series Providence), and the utterly striking and revealing Run for Your Life, where John Lennon borrows lyrics from the rockabilly classic Baby Let's Play House to express his envious, violent character at the time (during which he infamously beat his first wife, Cynthia, something he openly admitted to doing later in life) where he waxes veiled threats through lines such as "I'd rather see you dead girl, than with another boy" while explicitly stating that he's "a wicked chick," so naturally the albums ends on a rather unnerving note, something The Beatles had never done before. That being said, Rubber Soul is a major classic of 60's pop and deserves it's place as such for it's brilliance and influence.

The mystery that is The Beatles, with their hundreds of albums spanning a whole generation of time is slowly unravelling and dissolving in this tireless journey of mine. In fact, the group had only 13 albums recorded in just 7 years of its entire existence, and Rubber Soul is already their sixth, so I'm basically halfway through The Beatles! The 1001 Albums You Must Hear Before You Die skipped "Beatles for Sale" (1964) and "Help!" (1965) - I suppose they wouldn't pick every single album from the English band. Rubber Soul comes out swingin' with the use of new and unconventional instruments in rock, such as harmonium, fuzz bass, and most notably, the Indian sitar on "Norwegian Wood (This Bird Has Flown)" [and plenty of cowbell and maracas on other tracks]. By now The Beatles began moving away from their love themes, incorporating some philosophical messages into their songs, no doubt attributed to their by now "habitual use of marijuana", with Lennon himself referring to Rubber Soul as "the pot album." Maybe all this grass also caused some paranoia that started to strain the relationship between John and Paul. Just you wait, LSD is coming! We are also beginning to see the mastery of an album format (as opposed to a collection of singles, or just covers) with the band's only second album with all original material. The title is a reference to a phrase "plastic soul" which was a coined term for soul music written and performed by white musicians. Wouldn't you know?

Representing a giant artistic leap ahead both musically and lyrically for the Beatles, Rubber Soul took some of the subtler signs of maturity under the surface of A Hard Day's Night and ran with it on a riskier but entirely successful musical adventure. From a musical composition perspective, they began incorporating elements of cabaret, classical, folk, hard rock, and early psychedelia into their unmatched sense of pop songwriting. The instrumentation had branched out too, with piano, sitar, and a simulated harpsichord sound all prevalent on selected tracks. Lyrically, the songs were beginning to take a more reflective look at adult love, as opposed to the simple joys of holding hands. The aggressive "Run For Your Life" even threatens to murder a cheating lover, something that must have been astonishing to the those who were fans of the "She Loves You Yeah Yeah Yeah" days. Some of the Beatles' most timeless songs are present, but even more importantly, Rubber Soul showed the world of pop music that new possibilities awaited as the late 1960s approached.

Rubber Soul is the perfect combination of every great aspect of the Beatles. Many Beatles songs can feel slightly formulaic (i.e. their Beatlmania songs) or a bit too progressive (Revolver and beyond), yet Rubber Soul strikes a perfect balance with solid Rock/Folk performance accompanied by unique lyrics. Though the instrument selection is not as innovative as Sgt. Pepper?s, there?s a good amount of experimentation from the sitar in ?Norwegian Wood? to the subtle thumping of a matchbox in ?I?m Looking Through You?. The lyrics set a very melancholy tone that isn?t quite as obvious as the White Album. Sure, there are still songs about love, but there?s a lot more hesitance and sadness than their British Invasion era songs. ?Girl? and ?Michelle? discuss feelings of romantic detachment while ?In My Life? and ?Nowhere Man? reminisces what one has (or hasn?t) done with their life. The album is like a coming of age story and in this way acts as a great segue between the band?s pop albums to their more poetic and abstract albums. This transition is most clear on the album?s closer, an anti-love song telling a girl to ?Run For Your Life?. Quite a shocker from a band who wanted to hold your hand! It is one of the Beatles? finest pop, folk and psychedelic albums.

Rubber Soul, in case you can't read, refers to Soul Music, which was currently plaguing Britain so many moons ago in 1965, causing small children to do the 'popcorn' and the 'mashed potatoes' instead of their 'homework' as you and I well know they should be. And The Beatles got caught in the Soul Fog themselves (thankfully!) before going home down Folk Rock Way and ending up on Ballad Avenue like they'd planned. And dig that new car they're driving around...it's got all these bells and whistles on it like sitars and organs and stuff. That mechanic of theirs, that George Martin sho nuff is a mechanical wizard, you know. But thank God the Beatles know how to use all those aftermarket parts correctly. God knows what would happen if the Herman's delinquents got ahold of that stuff.

In which the first foot finally becomes firmly embedded in the muddy banks of that other shore.

Best song: NOWHERE MAN

It's all in the title, man - it's all in the title. Not that the title actually means anything (apparently it's Paul's periphrasing of "plastic soul", which has little to do with the record contents either), but like John once said, it's just the first Beatles album where they actually thought about an appropriate title. And an appropriate photo, might I add - perfectly attuned to the trippy clouds gathering on the horizon. That's about all that can be said about the album's supposed conceptualism, but it ain't that insignificant, either.

For many people, Rubber Soul has sort of become the quintessential Beatles record because it's exactly midway through the "early" and the "late" phases of their career. I don't quite feel that way because, although I have no problems with the band combining styles and genres on their albums, I do have a problem with "lightweight" stuff sitting right next to the "heavyweight" stuff; in the Beatles case, I usually prefer them separately. (And by "lightweight" stuff I do mean 'Wait' and 'You Won't See Me', but not 'Yellow Submarine', so there). But nitpicking is one thing, and joining the "sheepherd" loudly baahing out that with Rubber Soul, the Beatles In Rock have arrived is another. So count me in, good shepherd.

Rubber Soul is a true masterpiece, and one of the greatest albums in rock history. Marrying the immaculate melodies of albums like A Hard Day's Night to more ambitious songwriting, arrangements and production, the Beatles crafted an LP far ahead of its time and accordingly one of the most influential albums of its era. While it would be an egregious mistake to dismiss its predecessors as inconsequential childish fluff, the Beatles didn't truly come into their own until Rubber Soul, when they elevated themselves from mere rock stars to four of the most significant, pioneering figures in musical history.

I must confess that, silly me, I didn't much like this album the first couple of times I heard it. Oops. Needless to say, time has corrected this little mistake and allowed me to recognize this album for both the masterpiece it is and as a huge quantum leap forward from Help!. Regardless of what happened, whether Paul actually died of a car accident and was replaced by look-alike William Campbell (one of the weirdest Beatles legends), or whether they all had some sort of religious transformation while in India, or if they finally got some high-quality weed, the fact of the matter is that after this album, rock would never be the same.

If you consider this the best Beatles album, I have no problem with that. This is actually my brother's favorite, and really, the melodies are fantastic from start to finish. I do feel somewhat bad not giving it a perfect score, but it gets as high of a 5 stars as any album is capable of getting. And just think, they only got better ... What a band.
This to me is a Beatles greatest hits. I love every song off this album.

"Rubber Soul" is a pleasingly expressive record, more notable for the advances in the song writing of McCartney (he's less sentimental) and Lennon than it is as a completely satisfying musical statement; although Lennon's introspective turn was first heard on the "Beatles For Sale" LP from the preceding year. The playing on "Rubber Soul" is the Beatles' most assured since "A Hard Day's Night", and a number of the songs are exceptionally strong (Drive My Car; Norwegian Wood; Nowhere Man; In My Life; If I Needed Someone; Michelle; Girl), although these sit alongside a handful of less memorable, but well-performed compositions (You Won't See Me; Think For Yourself; The Word; I'm Looking Through You; Wait) and a couple of duff tracks (What Goes On; Run For Your Life). Much has been made of the sparseness of the recordings and production on "Rubber Soul". But it has to be said that the Beatles owe Bob Dylan (and the Byrds) a huge debt on this album; and any advances in this direction were short-lived and transitory anyway, swallowed up as they were by the phantasmagoria of sounds and confusion of themes on "Revolver", and all the Beatles' subsequent album releases.
The beginning of a very interesting, very unexpected, and very peculiar musical journey.
14 gems and a turning point in music...the concept album is born...and a special personal album for me
What I like most about this album is how it coheres, despite the new diversity in word and sound.

The best 60s rock album produced up to this point, which is saying a lot - there was in fact some stiff competition (e.g., The Beach Boys Today). Although the Beatles were still often sticking to their tried-and-true love song format (the cutesy "Drive My Car"; Paul's "You Won't See Me" and "Michelle"), John is experimenting with anthems ("The Word," which summarizes the whole flower power movement two years before it even happened), as well as highly personal, almost diary-like sketches that rank among his most popular work ("Norwegian Wood (This Bird Has Flown)," the first prominent rock record to feature a sitar; the devastating "In My Life"). It's all solid; even John's insecurely misogynistic "Run For Your Life" features a great vocal. The simultaneously released single ("We Can Work It Out"/"Day Tripper") was arguably their best to date.

With Revolver, the Beatles made the Great Leap Forward, reaching a previously unheard-of level of sophistication and fearless experimentation. Sgt. Pepper, in many ways, refines that breakthrough, as the Beatles consciously synthesized such disparate influences as psychedelia, art-song, classical music, rock & roll, and music hall, often in the course of one song. Not once does the diversity seem forced -- the genius of the record is how the vaudevillian "When I'm 64" seems like a logical extension of "Within You Without You" and how it provides a gateway to the chiming guitars of "Lovely Rita." There's no discounting the individual contributions of each member or their producer, George Martin, but the preponderance of whimsy and self-conscious art gives the impression that Paul McCartney is the leader of the Lonely Hearts Club Band. He dominates the album in terms of compositions, setting the tone for the album with his unabashed melodicism and deviously clever arrangements. In comparison, Lennon's contributions seem fewer, and a couple of them are a little slight but his major statements are stunning. "With a Little Help From My Friends" is the ideal Ringo tune, a rolling, friendly pop song that hides genuine Lennon anguish, … la "Help!"; "Lucy in the Sky With Diamonds" remains one of the touchstones of British psychedelia; and he's the mastermind behind the bulk of "A Day in the Life," a haunting number that skillfully blends Lennon's verse and chorus with McCartney's bridge. It's possible to argue that there are better Beatles albums, yet no album is as historically important as this. After Sgt. Pepper, there were no rules to follow -- rock and pop bands could try anything, for better or worse. Ironically, few tried to achieve the sweeping, all-encompassing embrace of music as the Beatles did here.

Care to take a glance at my ?classic? albums" Most of them have only been around for ten years or less. ?Classic?, right, it must sound suspicious. Currently in this day and age they are the shit to me, you know, and even have been for years ? but will they affect me in the same way in a decade or more from now" Sometimes I wonder. Sometimes I wonder if any of my favorites are really all that time resilient, collections of music in and of themselves exceptional and moving, without having to have some then-and-now emotional attachment placed on them by the glue-like nature of my humanity. I suppose that I?m not being too fair on of my music, though. After all, extended periods of time are really the only way to tell with this kind of thing, and you can?t really rush it, now can you"

But I?m not going to wait around for fifty-plus years to determine whether I should throw down the K.O. rating of rule-age for an album. Would you" No, that?s just crazy and obsessive, not to mention the fact that I probably won?t even care about it if I live that long. It?s not really fair, I guess: When you?ve only known an album for a few years, or even less, how can you be certain that it is, indeed, a timeless ?classic?" Especially if you happen to be my age and have, when compared to your elders, only recently taken an adamant interest in music; are there really, really any ?classics? that you, beyond a shadow of a doubt, believe deserve the title, albums that you are dead-positive will not lose their appeal to your person in the coming years"

I have but one, and one only: Let me introduce to you the greatest album of all time, Sgt. Pepper?s Lonely Hearts Club Band, the sole album that I can deem a true ?classic? in my eyes with the assurance that it will never lose its favor with me. Its history, its mere impact as the defining album of psychedelic rock ?n? roll makes it deserving of the title alone, but as does the lengthy amount of time that I?ve personally known Sgt. Pepper?s for, from the time of my father playing it in the background while I was in the crib as an infant to even now to this day as I play through it over and over as I type. The melodies and the revolutionary instrumentation of The Beatles recorded in the Abbey Road Studios in 1967 strike a sequence of notes in my mind each time that I hear it, playing back each and every instance or circumstance in which I had heard it throughout my life. ?Classic?, indeed.

The Beatles took the experimental breakthrough of Revolver in 1966 and completed what they had started in their following eighth studio album, Sgt. Pepper?s ? that?s right, completed. Their works before and after it" Damn ?classics? the lot of them, by many-a-standard, but a ?classic? of ?classics?" There is your Sgt. Pepper?s: The greatest album by the greatest band the world has ever known. The Fab Four set out to record an album that would effectively ?tour? for them at a time when they had left the touring world behind to become a studio-only band. Little did they know that not only would Sgt. Pepper?s effectively hit the road for them; it would ?tour? for them constantly in the decades following the 60s as a landmark of studio production wizardly, expanding the recording palette of those artists at the time of its release and that of those to come in the future. 

Legacy aside, the case can be made that Sgt. Pepper?s is The Beatles at their best creatively as songwriters, not a dud of a track to be found on the concept of the album?s setlist. Even Ringo Starr?s vocal performance is among the best of his career, heading one of The Beatles? premier, noteworthy tracks, ?With A Little Help From My Friends?, a song written for him by guitarist John Lennon and bassist Paul McCartney. A little underrated in his work on Sgt. Pepper?s, and on the majority of The Beatles? other albums as well, is George Harrison; his inclusions to the songs, especially the Indian-influenced and penned ?Within You Without You?, are vital to the album?s diversity of instrumental material, featuring such foreign inclusions as a tambura and dilrubha.

Leaving the rest of Sgt. Pepper?s to the hands of Lennon and McCartney is perhaps the reason the album succeeds as well as it does, though, taken in a song-by-song context. The overcomer?s anthem ?Getting Better?, the aforementioned ?With A Little Help From My Friends?, the often critically underrated beauty of ?She?s Leaving Home?, and hello, perhaps a runner for the greatest song of all time, the revolutionary epic ?A Day In The Life?" Lennon and McCartney at their best, prooving, if only by this album alone, that these two men were the greatest songwriting duo the world has ever known, performing the most cooperatively that they ever had together, a point that is all but cemented with just one play through of Sgt. Pepper?s enthralling closer. If only the singles released before the album were included into its tracklist, ?Penny Lane? and ?Strawberry Fields Forever?, then perhaps even the harshest of Sgt. Pepper's critics would bend to the album?s grandness as a sublime collection of songs and as a display of innovative studio wizardry. 

But on the other hand, Sgt. Pepper?s wouldn?t be the same then, now would it" The album?s perfect layout that meets the differing songs of its content with a firm handshake and places each preceding in perfect union with the next would be changed. In short, the album just wouldn?t worklike it does now. Give me an album that smoothly transitions from the mallet-struck painette of ?Getting Better? to the harpsichord and maracas of the psychedelic ?Fixing A Hole?, that bridges the gap of the out-there Indian instrumentals of ?Within You Without You? with the nursery-rhyme ditty found in ?When I?m Sixty-Four?, as if mere elementary mathematics. It just can?t be found anywhere else, a flow so natural and perfect that only the songwriting and studio workings of the greatest band of all time, The Beatles, could make it work. Let?s not forgot the studio marvel that is ?A Day In The Life?, a profound multi-piece revolving around drugs, a friend of McCartney and Lennon?s death, and pot holes in the road, featuring that final E-major chord, perhaps the grandest single chord in rock ?n? roll history. Ever wonder for what purpose it sounds"

Completion, it is finished. The end to the best work that The Beatles ever made together. But not only this: The chains of convention and pop music had once again been broken by The Fab Four with Sgt. Pepper?s release and impact in 1967, but arguably on a larger scale. No longer were songs by a pop band limited to a two-three minute running time in order to be successful. No longer were unconventional instrumentals totally off-limits for the radio; the gates of the studio had been opened wide. As I listen to Sgt. Pepper?s now, I have nothing but gratitude for what it stands for today and for what it did back then in the 60s, but yet I respect it the most for the strength as a timeless collection of songs. They have never diminished in their strength to me, never once becoming skippable on a listen through the album's entire length. Sgt. Pepper?s is an album that I must listen to all the way through each time I hear it, to remember each instance in which I experienced it, but also to marvel at the brilliance of its creators. And you know what" Every time I enjoy it a little more than the time before, perhaps a true indicator of Sgt. Pepper?s rightful status as a ?classic?, as the greatest album of all time:

?I?ve got to admit that it?s getting better; it?s getting better, all the time.?

The contemporary view was that this was not just the peak of the Beatles? career but the high point of recorded music to that date. Ringo remembered it less fondly as the album on which he learned to play chess.
It is where the Beatles really exploit the studio as the instrument, forgoing live playing for sonic adventure. It is impossible to overstate its impact: from a contemporary Sixties perspective it was utterly mind-blowing and original. Looking back from a point when its sonic innovations have been integrated into the mainstream, it remains a wonky, colourful and wildly improbable pop classic, although a little slighter and less cohesive than it may have seemed at the time.
Some songs, such as Lovely Rita, When I?m 64, Good Morning, Good Morning, Being For the Benefit of Mr Kite and Harrison?s dour, droning Within You Without You, seem undernourished excuses on which to hang florid ideas. But the title track is an improbable scorcher, Lucy in the Sky With Diamonds a glittering gem, Fixing a Hole and She?s Leaving Home lovely chamber pieces, and the concluding A Day in the Life one of the strangest and most beautiful recordings ever, an inner-space odyssey juxtaposing Lennon?s ethereal surrealism with McCartney?s prosaic energy and wrapping it all up in an apocalyptic orchestral climax.

For me, as a child of 16 at the time, this album was an epiphany. I was totally mesmerized from beginning to end, and remain that way to this day. Hearing it now, remastered and on far superior sound equipment, I am still dazzled by the bass on Fixing a Hole, the story line of She's Leaving Home, and the fact that it launched so much of what came after means nothing to me. For me, this was IT!...the album that really weened me off classical and jazz and into the world of rock.
This album isn't great. It's awe-inspiring. It is the most important album ever made. It transcends. It's like a William Blake poem book. It can be on both sides of the spectrum.

The huge historical impact of this album is without a doubt. In includes probably the best Beatles song ever made: "A Day in Life." But if you listen to it without the orthodoxy of the "best album ever made"? Or without a knowledge of the historical context (admitedly huge)? There are indeed perfect songs at the start, from the intro to "Getting Better", but you will find there are also McCartney-by-numbers like "Fixing a Hole," "Lovely Rita," "When I?m sixty-four" that almost kill the album in the middle of its running time. Lennon was that time coping with his drug addiction and he was unable to balance this album with some of his strong tracks. I do not think anybody can seriously recognize his tracks like "Mr. Kite," or "Good Morning" as his very best. He recovered artistically for the White album and there you will find "Dear Prudence," "Happiness is a Warm Gun," or "Revolution" - real songs of a genius he was. But on Sgt. Pepper? George Martin said it was a mistake not to include Strawberry Fields Forever/Penny Lane on the album and he is right. The album could have been so much stronger. Album easy to admire for its historical value but pretty hard to love.

Well it was forty eight years ago today, that The Beatles made arguably the best album of all time under a pseudonym that pushed all boundaries and changed music forever...ay. Okay it doesn't fit the time measure needed for the first line but it has lots of truth to it. The Beatles took a softer rock approach than Revolver and tried even more unconventional instruments and concepts.

The intro track is a good rocker and sets the tone, entering the druggy and cheerful "A Little Help From My Friends" where Ringo once again assumes the role of the happy clown and for good reason, he is well fitted for it, and the Beatles provide great harmonies. We get "Lucy in the Sky With Diamonds" next, a Beatles classic for good reason, it's spacey and represents everything the psychedelic 60s embodied. The best songs here are the ones fair weather fans don't know. "Getting Better" is a personal favourite, not only because it's great guitar but because of the bridge where John and Paul collaborate, it goes from happy rocker to druggy, and the lyrics take a strange turn "I Used to be Cruel to my Woman I beat her and kept her apart from the things that she loved." It threw me for a loop when I first heard that, I couldn't even believe it was part of the same song. "Fixing a Hole" is just as pleasant, Paul sounds mesmerizing with "Where It Will Gooooo..." Follow this up with "She's Leaving" which is a gorgeous song by Paul and one of the saddest The Beatles recorded, about a runaway that is very symbolic of the rift between the counterculture and their predecessors, made all the more fascinating by focusing on the parents rather than the child.

John steps back in with "Being for the Benefit of Mr. Kite!" A song inspired by an old carnival poster and it is one of my favourites, it's a detour from the rock based sound most of the album has and is an example of how avant-garde can be used properly. Certainly better here than Rev 9. It's unfortunate George only gets one song (especially since "It's All Too Much" was recorded during these sessions) but his contribution "Within You, Without You" is as smooth as honey, a perfect usage of Indian music and it's philosophical musings fit perfectly with the era it was recorded in. After this we get two charming ditties by Paul ("When I'm 64" and "Lovely Rita") that are both great, but despite that they'll always be remembered for replacing the super duo of Penny Lane and Strawberry Fields. Then there's "Good Morning, Good Morning" which I think has the weakest chorus but makes up for it through eccentricities. Then there's the reprise followed by

"A Day in the Life". Greatest Beatles song ever? Possibly. It has Paul and John trading verses, a sweet acoustic guitar, and best of all a huge build up to a phenomenal climax. Most times I listen to an album I have to listen to it many times to appreciate it but with Sgt Pepper's it was once and I knew I heard something special. The Fab Four were never this unified again.

The Big Cheese. The Head Honcho. The King Rat. The Leper With The Most Fingers. Sgt. Pepper's has such an enormous, hulking historic value that to even approach it objectively is more or less impossible nowadays unless you live on a desert island. A whole generation of newly-freaky-in-1967 folks still get misty-eyed about this one, it's still a sort of coming-of-age record for a lot of young folks even today. Okay...I started on this road, and now I'm a gonna finish it.

So, see, the kids who were 13 or 14 when the Beatles first arrived, had their first date with Hard Day's Night (probably went to see the film), had their first heartbreak along with Beatles For Sale, started getting teenage angst with Help!, got wasted for the first times with Rubber Soul, turned 18 or 19 when this record came out and were totally open to the invitation to get 'turned on'. As the Beatles matured and went through their changes, the 60's and the kids did the same. And to explain what it felt like when this album was released, try to imagine your favorite band not releasing an album (not even a compilation!) for nearly 7 months, an unheard of length of time in the 1960's, during which time exciting and scary changes were happening to music, the world, and yourself at such a rapid pace that anything was possible from the Beatles in 1967. It was like the anticipation for the followup to Dark Side Of The Moon in the 70's, or to The Joshua Tree in the 80's, or OK Computer in the 90's, but even bigger...because in the 1960's, the Beatles were something that everyone agreed on. Nothing has happened like that since. According to the old folks I know, The Beatles were just the top of everyone's list. The Rolling Stones were for greasers, the Who was unknown, Dylan was for arty flakes, and who else was there? But everyone loved the Beatles, and everyone was waiting for Sgt. Pepper's.

And you know what? They delivered on their hype. The unforgettable, colorful album cover, the moustaches, the cardboard cutouts, the lyric sheet. It had A CONCEPT!! Image that! And the music...oooh, that music just hit all the right spots. Just ditching your square parents for an adventurous life on your own? You get 'She's Leaving Home'. Just taken your first LSD trip? You get 'Lucy In the Sky With Diamonds'. Just getting in the communal groovin' mood with your freaky friends? You get 'With A Little Help From My Friends'. Ruminating on the meaning of life and the falsity of 'normal' lifestyles? You get 'A Day In The Life'. It was an unstoppable machine. Everyone was talking about it, everyone was playing it, everyone was trying to understand it. And everyone else in the music world tried to imitate it. It was what everyone had wanted, and more.

I'm going to be brutally honest, I'm a Beatles fan and I really don't care for this album. It has some really cool sounding tracks like Being for the Benefit of Mr. Kite, Lucy in the Sky with Diamonds and A Day in the Life but to me it just seemed so empty, so full of style yet so lacking of substance (compared with their Beatlemania works and their post Sgt. Peppers works). It was sonically groundbreaking at the time and parts of it still sound cool as I just mentioned but if you ask me it just came off as this rather pretentious sonic experiment that only occasionally connected on an emotional or cerebral level.

Well, here it is, the most famous album in the history of mankind. As overrated by some as it is underrated by others, and while my opinion of the album is only a drop in the ocean of essays and critiques of it, here it is anyways. Is the album overrated? Sure. Is it the greatest album of all time? No. Is it the greatest Beatles album of all time? No. Is it the most 'experimental' album of all time? Not exactly. Is it one of the top ten or so albums of all time? Possibly. Is there anyway it will get less than a 5 stars on my overall scale? NO.

This album rules. When I first got it, I probably would have only given it, ehn, a 4 stars or so, but I was dumb. There have been greater albums in rock history, but not many. Buy it.

More than any album that had been made or will ever be made, Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band transcends all boundaries and rewrites the books on how rock 'n' roll is and was supposed to sound. Having retired from the road, the album is both of and ahead of its time and the Beatles had completely mastered their craft and had used the studio to.their total advantage. Sgt. Pepper encompasses style, the psychedelic movement, the different musical forms, it defines perfection. While the Sgt. Pepper band is largely a Paul McCartney brainstorm, Messrs Lennon, Harrison, and Starr cannot be understated, for their contributions make the album whole and cohesive. All tracks are key to establishing the Pepper sound and to take one away would be doing it a disservice.

This album is unique because it opened musical horizons for all the other artists that followed. The Beatles and George Martin introduced new elements into their sound that basically said anything goes in rock music. Boundaries were shattered and there was no looking back. It?s hard to demonstrate to the current generation the anticipation that we felt at the time when a new Beatles album came out. We always expected and got great music. Even when the Beatles did covers. Sgt Pepper exceeded our expectations by a margin that we hadn?t even measured. You can never know the thrill of sitting in your parent?s living room and listening to all that psychedelic music being played on a two speaker stereo system. Yes it?s flawed but there was nothing like it before and a lot of imitation after. This is why Sgt Pepper is the best album of all time. There are and will always be new contenders but only one can be the first one.

There's a reason this album is considered one of the greatest of all time. Because it is.

I love The Beatles and all of their albums. I've heard Rubber Soul, With The Beatles, The White Album, Let It Be etc. millions of times. But Sgt. Peppers is their masterpiece.

A stunningly consistent album from start to finish, this is the Beatles' ultimate achievement.

This is often to be said the greatest or the best album ever. It is a very good album. The Beatles was probably inspired by The Beach Boys who said they had made the best album PET SOUNDS which was inspired by RUBBER SOUL. Of course, like all the BEATLES fans know, "Rubber Soul" and "Revolver" are much better than PET SOUNDS by The Beach Boys. "Pepper" is also better. The Beatles's style had changed quite much and I understood that no one had made album like this before. "With the Little Help from My Friends", "Lucy in the Sky With Diamonds", "She's Leaving Home" and even the odd "A Day in the Life" are now classics. Still, there's songs as "Good Morning" and "Mr. Kite" which you had to just take by humor. "When I'm Sixty-Four" is a song we used to listen to school while we were young.

SPLHCB is worthy of most of the hype that surrounds it, a brilliant album that pairs superb songwriting and ubiquitous clever experimentation, with the two complementing one another as opposed to clashing. While it may not deserve its reputation as the best album of all time, or even the best Beatles album of all time, it's nonetheless a true classic, and one that will endure for years to come.

The whole concept that there is such a thing as the greatest album of all time is silly. Silly, yes, but it sure is fun to postulate and argue our choices. Sgt. Pepper is one of the albums that has been historically mentioned in discussions of the greatest albums ever and as such has been subjected to a bunch of revisionist history nonsense. I understand it is a time honored sport to try and butcher sacred cows, but what I do not understand why in some corners it is believed that by acknowledging the greatness of one album somehow diminishes the greatness of another. Yes, I am talking about Sgt. Pepper?s vs. Pet Sounds and how often they are pitted against each other. I find this strange and sad since they are really kindred spirits of the 1960?s. What I know is that to me Sgt. Pepper sounds great, especially when listened beginning to end. I could go on talking about McCartney?s epic basslines, Lennon?s voice on A Day in the Life etc. but nothing I write will change anyone?s mind. Sgt. Pepper is a great listen. Simple as that. 

Another user review on AMG of Sgt. Pepper mentioned something John Lennon supposedly said about Ringo - "Ringo isn't the best drummer in the world. He isn't even the best drummer in the Beatles". I had heard this funny quote too, but recently found out that Lennon never said it.
From a story in the L.A. Times by Randy Lewis, Beatles expert Mark Lewisohn discredits this quote as having come from John Lennon: 

As part of his in-depth research, Lewisohn also has debunked a humorous knock on Starr?s drumming abilities, long attributed to John Lennon. For decades, people and media outlets have repeated the anecdote about Lennon being asked whether he considered Starr to be the best drummer in the world. The oft-quoted response: ?He?s not even the best drummer in the Beatles.?
While it sounds like the kind of acerbic comment that might have come out of Lennon?s mouth, Lewisohn says no.
?The London Times newspaper quoted John Lennon ?famously saying that Ringo wasn?t even the best drummer in the Beatles.? John Lennon never said that, famously or otherwise, and that is the London Times quoting him,? Lewisohn said, making a point about his motivation for trying to separate fact from Fab Four mythology.
?For me, it?s [a case of tracking down] when did he say this? I?ve heard every John Lennon interview, I?ve read every John Lennon interview, I never saw that quote. So when did he say it, let alone when did he famously say it?? he said. ?I determined to get to the bottom of it. And it?s actually a TV comedian?s joke from three years after John was killed, in 1983. So John Lennon never said it -- and wouldn?t have said it.?
The line often attributed to John Lennon - "Ringo isn't the best drummer in the world. He isn't even the best drummer in the Beatles" - was actually uttered by British comedian Jasper Carrott in 1983.
Great album from one of the greatest band of music history, Fabulous outro with A Day in The Life at end, so beautiful.

Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band is arguably the most important Beatles album, building upon the discoveries of Revolver while also being new and wholly diverse, and the mixing is far superior than in previous records.

Retired from touring permanently (although nobody knew it at the time), another extended rest, and time away from each other. Building even more on the majesty and accomplishments of Revolver, the Beatles reconvene in the studio and become purely a studio band. Pushing the boundaries even further on what a studio can do as an instrument unto itself, Sgt. Pepper is the ultimate culmination of what a rock album can be. The artistic statement of all artistic statements.

Yet, at the same time, the amount of technical achievement here can be a bit overwhelming. Sure, the songs here are among the best the band ever put out, but it sounds like it was recorded with another world in mind today. But that's not to diminish what the album is and what it did at the time of its release. It still stands as an extraordinary accomplishment.

While nothing here really rocks out like their earlier material, the songs remain mostly as catchy as ever. Paul McCartney turns in catchy pop like "Lovely Rita" and "Getting Better", channels the music hall with "When I'm Sixty-Four", spins another soap opera tale with "She's Leaving Home" and plays the carnival barker of sorts with the title track. John Lennon isn't quite as introspective here, turning out psychedelic fare like "Lucy in the Sky with Diamonds", "Being For the Benefit of Mr. Kite" and "Good Morning Good Morning". George's Indian mysticism continues with "Within You Without You". And Lennon and McCartney come together for the album's magnum opus, the apocalyptic "A Day in the Life" complete with druggy imagery, surging orchestration, and the final piano chord like a door slamming shut on the past and resonating into the future of rock music.

This is the album where rock ceased being pop and became what we know as classic rock. Revolver may be the Beatles' best album, but Sgt. Pepper is the supreme musical statement of all time.

Some things need to be said 

The Beatles were the biggest band on the face of the earth during the mid sixties. Having progressed from an energetic Beat band playing Rock N Roll songs in clubs to headlining across the world with a string of number ones, two feature films and millions of screaming girls at their tail. John, Paul, Ringo and George had managed to hit a chord with almost everyone, with everything that they touched turning to gold. The Beatles could tackle any genre imaginable and make it work. Rock N Roll, Blues, Folk, Baroque and even Avant Garde psychedelia. Off the path of their mega hit album Revolver, the band were dipping their toes into studio experimentation. With their song 'Tomorrow Never Knows', the band had successfully combined Psychedelic rock with several tape loops and effects to create a truly mesmerizing piece of music. Leaving their touring days behind and now working in the studio full time, expectations were colossally high for the Fab Four's next record. With the release of the Single 'Penny Lane' b/w 'Strawberry Fields Forever', two of the greatest songs of the 1960s, the band were dead set on delivering a classic. On the first of June, Sgt. Pepper's Lonley Hearts Club Band was unleashed upon the world. As expected the album was critically acclaimed, staying at the top of the charts for months and having a lasting effect on modern music as whole. Eventually it was voted as the greatest album of all time by Rolling Stone magazine, a highly prestigious honor. Even today Sgt Pepper continues to be lauded as a masterpiece that no album can touch. The gold standard. The cream of the crop as it were. 

Disregarding Sgt Pepper is seen as suicide in the music journalistic group. Sgt Pepper is something never to be critiqued. Never to be spoken badly of. While some critics have come forward denouncing the album, even other artists (Famously Frank Zappa stated that The Rolling Stones 'Between The Buttons' was a superior album) have taken pot shots at the album. I'm not going to sugarcoat my views because frankly in my opinion, Sgt Pepper is the most disgustingly overrated album of all time. Now that I've guaranteed my crucifixion, let me explain myself. I can appreciate this record for what it is. A step forward in musical history. In my opinion, It's not that good. While the production is slick and clean, the album is muddled with dropped ideas and an over all lack of adventure to it. Numerous McCartney Music hall pieces outway many of Lennon's and Harrison's tracks. Songs like 'When I'm 64' and 'Fixing A Hole' bring the record down compared to 'A Day In The Life' and 'Lucy In The Sky'. I don't hate this album but the Beatles perfected a wider range of tracks with Revolver the year prior, hosting a much wider range of genres and ideas, like Acid Rock, Baroque and even Jazz/Soul. Sgt Pepper isn't bad, but it's weighed down by its own ego and Paul McCartney's love for Music Hall

Here's a review you never heard before... This is my least favorite Beatles album. Had the Beatles taken two songs out of this album and put them in "Magical Mystery Tour", St. Pepper would be a throw away album. "Magical Mystery Tour " would then be the greatest rock album of all eternity with nothing else even coming close. What are those two songs ? "A day in the life" and " Lucy in the Sky with Diamonds"

Maybe the best rock album ever. Maybe not. But buy it anyway.

Best song: hell, they're all great!

Ah, the most famous rock album of all time. In fact, it's so famous I just can't listen to it any more, which only further proves its greatness. This is the peak of the Beatles' experimentation, the peak of their psychedelic period, and probably the peak of their songwriting skills. So who cares if it's not rock music really, it's a blend of all possible styles. It's not that there are no guitars: it's just that they are completely overshadowed by strings, symphonic orchestras, mellotrones and lotsa stuff that was so new and original then and is so common and boring now. Hey, don't get me wrong: it's not the music they did then that is common, it's the music that others do now that is so.

Sgt Pepper was certainly not the most experimental album of all time, if you put a sign of equality between the words 'experimentation' and 'noisemaking'. What is really so crucial about Sgt Pepper is that it was this album, and not any other, that led serious music lovers, many 'classical snobs' included, to finally recognize rock music as a serious, independent trend in modern art. While Frank Zappa was too 'crazy' to be considered 'worthy', the Beach Boys spoiled all the fun with their Hollywood arrangements, and Bob Dylan was still primarily a lyricist, the Beatles did it exactly the right way, and nobody can get away from the fact. Sgt Pepper lives on!

The "Sgt Pepper" album was recorded in a four-month span beginning in 1966. The advent of new studio techniques such as multitrack recording and pitch shifting [recording tracks at different speeds] as well as the band's increasingly diverse influences led to "Sgt. Pepper's" kaleidoscope of sound experiments {music hall, Western and Eastern classical, rock 'n' roll]. The album, from the pop-art packaging to the gapless track sequencing, successfully put forth the idea that music and art were synonymous

Since the release of the Beatles' "Rubber Soul" in 1965, pop music critics and fans have been in the habit of listening to an album not simply as a collection of individual songs, but as a total entity - as a work of Art. On these terms "Sgt. Pepper" is a superior release to the preceding "Revolver", because the overarching concept of a variety show performance and its song links pull the disparate threads of the Beatles' song writing and performance into a whole that is greater than the sum of its parts. "Sgt. Pepper" can't be called a great rock record, but that's only because most of the songs aren't rock (although the parameters of rock are in the process of being widened here). Which means "A Hard Day's Night" could just as easily bear the mantle of Greatest Rock Record Ever Made, although it depends on the criteria you are using, and what kind of experience you are looking for in a pop record. If technical achievement and creative innovation are the yardsticks, then "Sgt. Pepper" must beat both "Revolver" and "A Hard Day's Night" in the Greatest Beatles Album debate. However, if ensemble playing and overall quality of songs is more critical (something Beatles records from "Revolver" onwards sorely lack), then you might expect to find the best Beatles record among their earliest recordings. Happily, when it comes to actually listening to the records, the decision of which one to pick is a much easier choice; and each record can be enjoyed for its own individual qualities, which makes the task of searching out the best Beatles record unnecessary, and rather tedious, and not at all in the spirit in which the record was made; although, regrettably, it is the Beatles' reaching up for pop immortality on LPs like "Revolver" and "Sgt. Pepper" that led to an unhealthy preoccupation in rock with 'maturity' and 'growth', and making major statements. On "Sgt. Pepper" the Beatles, for all their flights of fancy, manage to keep proceedings down to earth - not too surprising with McCartney at the helm - although the slight edge in McCartney's lyrics in places may surprise listeners, and is one of the elements of the make-up of "Sgt Pepper" (along with the immaculate track order, and overall presentation) that lends the album rather more weight than its playful veneer might suggest.

For the first 12 songs, I really felt like The Beatles were nowhere. And if it were real, Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band would be alien. I was amazed not only by the technical innovations, but mostly by the way in which they were used to elevate music. Every single one of these songs sounded decades ahead of their time. What we are witnessing here, people, is modern music's connection to the high arts. From now on, every single great record would aspire to this monolithic masterpiece. But the first to do that were The Beatles themselves. On the last song, "A Day In the Life", The Beatles came back, forever transformed; and from the heavenly realm of Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band we were put back on earth were death, war and political turmoil is perennial. But this song ushered in a new beginning. Every single great album ever made from that time forward owes this! And for that, John Winston Lennon, James Paul McCartney, Richard Starkey and George Harrison - thank you! Thank you for making the greatest album ever!

The Beatlemania has officially dried up. The touring has ended and Harrison has even threated to leave the band after his six-week India soul-searching trip. In fact, The Beatles, as the rock band topping the Billboard charts, were nearly finished. Instead, an Edwardian-era military band emerged as an alter ego, for the very first conceptual studio album, giving the x-fab-four the freedom to experiment in the studio with pieces that could never be really performed live. And experiment they did, producing compositions that were more baroque pop, vaudeville, music hall, and even Indian classical music, then the standard psychedelic rock and pop of the era. Recorded on EMI's Studer J37 four-track, George Martin pushed the signal processing limits of the studio equipment, to shape the sound with more dynamic range compression, signal limiting, pitch control, and even ambiophonics (an effect creating a 'stereo triangle' binaural soundfield to virtualize a perception of the surround sound). The newly invented "flanger" nearly came out from Martin's joke that Lennon's voice has been "treated with a double vibrocated sploshing flange..."Besides the many drug-induced references, from the now well-known "Lucy in the Sky with Diamonds" hidden acronym, to the "Henry the Horse" phrase, to "Fixing a Hole", the psychedelic era is also promptly displayed on the magnificent album cover, by the pop artists Peter Blake and Jann Haworth - a kaleidoscopic collage of 57 photographs "as a guidebook to the cultural topography of the decade." With Paul McCartney, of course, being the Sgt. Pepper himself, his newly devised Lonely Hearts Club band produced a historically important album - a true artistic maturation and a fearless breakthrough that can only follow on the heels of the Revolver and Rubber Soul.

It's not perfect, but the role it played in the history of music cannot be disregarded -- this is an album that pioneered various production techniques, added to the rising idea that a rock band can be artists, and popularized the idea that an album can be more than just a list of individual tracks. The concept of the album and the way its conveyed falls very short (even some songs are clich‚ beatles), but it's everything else that is monumental. It's tracks like the very first two or last one that elevate this album as a landmark of the 60s.

Having already hinted at a huge leap forward in popular music with Rubber Soul, then made a large stride towards it with Revolver, the Beatles had an opportunity to create the album that would forever change the game and permanently etch them into the history books. They didn't pass it up.

From the vast intelligent combinations of different musical styles that had either come before or been recently discovered in the West, to the album being released identically Worldwide without exception (yes, including on Capitol in the U.S.), Sgt. Pepper wiped the slate clean and drew up a fresh one, to the Fab Four's own grand design.

It's an album that produced no singles, yet still feels as though it is packed with hits that will never, ever be forgotten. This really is the greatest studio rock band of all-time and right here, on the greatest studio rock album of all-time, is nearly 40 minutes' proof of it.

With Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band, the Beatles fully shed their mop-top image and the "She Loves You" era of their music. They fully immersed themselves in the studio experimentation and psychedelia that had been increasingly present on Rubber Soul and Revolver. Sound effects, Eastern influences, looping, orchestral music, sitar, calliope, and a host of other techniques, sounds, and instruments are brought into play on the group's most conceptually ambitious record to this point in their career. Despite all of these additions, Lennon and McCartney had lost not of their unrivaled pop sense as songwriters, and thus songs like "With a Little Help From My Friends," "When I'm Sixty-Four," and "A Day in the Life" feature melodies as infectious as anything from the "I Want to Hold Your Hand" days. The sonic leap forward that this album made established it as a historic record and one that inspired much to come on the rock and pop music fronts, but it was the high quality songwriting of the band which truly makes the record arguably the most enduring pop record of the prolific 1960s.

The most famous rock record in history, and it deserves most of the acclaim. What seems to have been forgotten in all the hoopla is that the songs mostly just expand and consolidate earlier innovations that were played out on Revolver - showcases of complex orchestration ("A Day In The Life"), abrasive, slice-of-life rockers ("Good Morning Good Morning"), giddy 60s anthems ("It's Getting Better"), bizarre studio experiments ("Being For The Benefit Of Mr. Kite"), George's Indian-influenced pearls of wisdom ("Within You Without You"), and especially the lush psychedelia that John had mastered ("Lucy In The Sky With Diamonds"). Even "She's Leaving Home" is a bathetic rip-off of the more sincere "Eleanor Rigby," and the title track's booming, unstoppable herd- of-elephants sound is mirrored by "Taxman." Say what you might, though, the record did blow open the 60s like a double-strength hit of Purple Haze.
